htmlEmbed:
Ensuring Comprehensive Care and Support for Transgender and Gender-Diverse Children and Adolescents@AmerAcadPeds8/30/2018

As a traditionally underserved population that faces numerous health disparities, youth who identify as transgender and gender diverse (TGD) and their families are increasingly presenting to pediatric providers for education, care, and referrals. The need for more formal training, standardized treatment, and research on safety and medical outcomes often leaves providers feeling ill equipped to support and care for patients that identify as TGD and families. In this policy statement, we review relevant concepts and challenges and provide suggestions for pediatric providers that are focused on promoting the health and positive development of youth that identify as TGD while eliminating discrimination and stigma.

gender identity, mental health, gender, transgender personsRead

<meta property="og:title" content="Ensuring Comprehensive Care and Support for Transgender and Gender-Diverse Children and Adolescents" />
<meta property="og:description" content="As a traditionally underserved population that faces numerous health disparities, youth who identify as transgender and gender diverse (TGD) and their families are increasingly presenting to pediatric providers for education, care, and referrals. The need for more formal training, standardized treatment, and research on safety and medical outcomes often leaves providers feeling ill equipped to support and care for patients that identify as TGD and families. In this policy statement, we review relevant concepts and challenges and provide suggestions for pediatric providers that are focused on promoting the health and positive development of youth that identify as TGD while eliminating discrimination and stigma." />

        <meta property="og:site_name" content="American Academy of Pediatrics"/>
        <meta property="og:type" content="article"/>
        <meta property="og:title" content="Ensuring Comprehensive Care and Support for Transgender and Gender-Diverse Children and Adolescents"/>
        <meta property="og:description" content="As a traditionally underserved population that faces numerous health disparities, youth who identify as transgender and gender diverse (TGD) and their families are increasingly presenting to pediatric providers for education, care, and referrals. The need for more formal training, standardized treatment, and research on safety and medical outcomes often leaves providers feeling ill equipped to support and care for patients that identify as TGD and families. In this policy statement, we review relevant concepts and challenges and provide suggestions for pediatric providers that are focused on promoting the health and positive development of youth that identify as TGD while eliminating discrimination and stigma."/>

<div class="article-body">
    <div id="articleMainView-articleId" class="js-articleMainView-articleId" data-articleid="37381" style="display: none;"></div>
    <div id="ContentTab" class="content active">
    <div class="widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-ArticleFulltext">
        <input type="hidden" name="js-hfArticleLinksReferencesDoiRegex" id="js-hfArticleLinksReferencesDoiRegex" value="" />
<div class="module-widget">
    <div class="widget-items" data-widgetname="ArticleFulltext">

            <div class="article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix"></div>




                <div id="7280782" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <section class="abstract"><p>As a traditionally underserved population that faces numerous health disparities, youth who identify as transgender and gender diverse (TGD) and their families are increasingly presenting to pediatric providers for education, care, and referrals. The need for more formal training, standardized treatment, and research on safety and medical outcomes often leaves providers feeling ill equipped to support and care for patients that identify as TGD and families. In this policy statement, we review relevant concepts and challenges and provide suggestions for pediatric providers that are focused on promoting the health and positive development of youth that identify as TGD while eliminating discrimination and stigma.</p></section>
                </div>
                    <div class="article-metadata-panel clearfix rs_skip">
    <div class="widget-SolrResourceMetadata widget-instance-ContentMetadata_ArticleFulltext_Article">
        
        <div class="content-metadata-subjects">
            <div class="content-metadata-subjects-title">Subjects: </div>
                    <a  class="developmental/behavioral-issues" href="/pediatrics/search-results?exPrm_fq=Subjects:"Developmental%2fBehavioral+Issues"">Developmental/Behavioral Issues</a><span>,</span>
                    <a class="psychosocial-issues" href="/pediatrics/search-results?exPrm_fq=Subjects:"Psychosocial+Issues"">Psychosocial Issues</a>
        </div>
        <div class="content-metadata-topics">
            <div class="content-metadata-topics-title">Topics:</div>
                    <a href="/pediatrics/search-results?f_SemanticFilterTopics=gender">gender</a><span>,</span>
                    <a href="/pediatrics/search-results?f_SemanticFilterTopics=transgender persons">transgender persons</a><span>,</span>
                    <a href="/pediatrics/search-results?f_SemanticFilterTopics=gender identity">gender identity</a><span>,</span>
                    <a href="/pediatrics/search-results?f_SemanticFilterTopics=mental health">mental health</a>
        </div>


 
    </div>

                    </div>
            <h2 scrollto-destination="7280783" data-legacyid="s01" id="7280783" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Introduction</h2>
            <div >
                <div id="7280784" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>In its dedication to the health of all children, the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) strives to improve health care access and eliminate disparities for children and teenagers who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, or questioning (LGBTQ) of their sexual or gender identity.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B1" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>1</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B2" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>2</sup></a> Despite some advances in public awareness and legal protections, youth who identify as LGBTQ continue to face disparities that stem from multiple sources, including inequitable laws and policies, societal discrimination, and a lack of access to quality health care, including mental health care. Such challenges are often more intense for youth who do not conform to social expectations and norms regarding gender. Pediatric providers are increasingly encountering such youth and their families, who seek medical advice and interventions, yet they may lack the formal training to care for youth that identify as transgender and gender diverse (TGD) and their families.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B3" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>3</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280785" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>This policy statement is focused specifically on children and youth that identify as TGD rather than the larger LGBTQ population, providing brief, relevant background on the basis of current available research and expert opinion from clinical and research leaders, which will serve as the basis for recommendations. It is not a comprehensive review of clinical approaches and nuances to pediatric care for children and youth that identify as TGD. Professional understanding of youth that identify as TGD is a rapidly evolving clinical field in which research on appropriate clinical management is limited by insufficient funding.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B3" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>3</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B4" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>4</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h2 scrollto-destination="7280786" data-legacyid="s02" id="7280786" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Definitions</h2>
            <div >
                <div id="7280787" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>To clarify recommendations and discussions in this policy statement, some definitions are provided. However, brief descriptions of human behavior or identities may not capture nuance in this evolving field.</p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280788" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>“Sex,” or “natal gender,” is a label, generally “male” or “female,” that is typically assigned at birth on the basis of genetic and anatomic characteristics, such as genital anatomy, chromosomes, and sex hormone levels. Meanwhile, “gender identity” is one’s internal sense of who one is, which results from a multifaceted interaction of biological traits, developmental influences, and environmental conditions. It may be male, female, somewhere in between, a combination of both, or neither (ie, not conforming to a binary conceptualization of gender). Self-recognition of gender identity develops over time, much the same way as a child’s physical body does. For some people, gender identity can be fluid, shifting in different contexts. “Gender expression” refers to the wide array of ways people display their gender through clothing, hair styles, mannerisms, or social roles. Exploring different ways of expressing gender is common for children and may challenge social expectations. The way others interpret this expression is referred to as “gender perception” (<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="t1" data-open="t1" class="link link-reveal link-table xref-fig">Table 1</a>).<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B5" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>5</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B6" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>6</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280789" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <a id = "7280789" scrollto-destination="7280789"></a><div content-id="t1 s02" class="table-wrap table-wide"><div id="t1" data-id="t1" class="table-wrap-title "><span class="label">TABLE 1</span><div class="caption"><p>Relevant Terms and Definitions Related to Gender Care</p></div> </div><div class="table-overflow"><table><thead name="thead" align=""><tr><th>Term<span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th><th>Definition<span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Sex </td><td>An assignment that is made at birth, usually male or female, typically on the basis of external genital anatomy but sometimes on the basis of internal gonads, chromosomes, or hormone levels </td></tr><tr><td>Gender identity </td><td>A person’s deep internal sense of being female, male, a combination of both, somewhere in between, or neither, resulting from a multifaceted interaction of biological traits, environmental factors, self-understanding, and cultural expectations </td></tr><tr><td>Gender expression </td><td>The external way a person expresses their gender, such as with clothing, hair, mannerisms, activities, or social roles </td></tr><tr><td>Gender perception </td><td>The way others interpret a person’s gender expression </td></tr><tr><td>Gender diverse </td><td>A term that is used to describe people with gender behaviors, appearances, or identities that are incongruent with those culturally assigned to their birth sex; gender-diverse individuals may refer to themselves with many different terms, such as transgender, nonbinary, genderqueer,<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B7" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>7</sup></a> gender fluid, gender creative, gender independent, or noncisgender. “Gender diverse” is used to acknowledge and include the vast diversity of gender identities that exists. It replaces the former term, “gender nonconforming,” which has a negative and exclusionary connotation. </td></tr><tr><td>Transgender </td><td>A subset of gender-diverse youth whose gender identity does not match their assigned sex and generally remains persistent, consistent, and insistent over time; the term “transgender” also encompasses many other labels individuals may use to refer to themselves. </td></tr><tr><td>Cisgender </td><td>A term that is used to describe a person who identifies and expresses a gender that is consistent with the culturally defined norms of the sex they were assigned at birth </td></tr><tr><td>Agender </td><td>A term that is used to describe a person who does not identify as having a particular gender </td></tr><tr><td>Affirmed gender </td><td>When a person’s true gender identity, or concern about their gender identity, is communicated to and validated from others as authentic </td></tr><tr><td>MTF; affirmed female; trans female </td><td>Terms that are used to describe individuals who were assigned male sex at birth but who have a gender identity and/or expression that is asserted to be more feminine </td></tr><tr><td>FTM; affirmed male; trans male </td><td>Terms that are used to describe individuals who were assigned female sex at birth but who have a gender identity and/or expression that is asserted to be more masculine </td></tr><tr><td>Gender dysphoria </td><td>A clinical symptom that is characterized by a sense of alienation to some or all of the physical characteristics or social roles of one’s assigned gender; also, gender dysphoria is the psychiatric diagnosis in the <em>DSM-5</em>, which has focus on the distress that stems from the incongruence between one’s expressed or experienced (affirmed) gender and the gender assigned at birth. </td></tr><tr><td>Gender identity disorder </td><td>A psychiatric diagnosis defined previously in the <em>DSM-IV</em> (changed to “gender dysphoria” in the <em>DSM-5</em>); the primary criteria include a strong, persistent cross-sex identification and significant distress and social impairment. This diagnosis is no longer appropriate for use and may lead to stigma, but the term may be found in older research. </td></tr><tr><td>Sexual orientation </td><td>A person’s sexual identity in relation to the gender(s) to which they are attracted; sexual orientation and gender identity develop separately. </td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="table-modal"><table><thead name="thead" align=""><tr><th>Term<span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th><th>Definition<span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Sex </td><td>An assignment that is made at birth, usually male or female, typically on the basis of external genital anatomy but sometimes on the basis of internal gonads, chromosomes, or hormone levels </td></tr><tr><td>Gender identity </td><td>A person’s deep internal sense of being female, male, a combination of both, somewhere in between, or neither, resulting from a multifaceted interaction of biological traits, environmental factors, self-understanding, and cultural expectations </td></tr><tr><td>Gender expression </td><td>The external way a person expresses their gender, such as with clothing, hair, mannerisms, activities, or social roles </td></tr><tr><td>Gender perception </td><td>The way others interpret a person’s gender expression </td></tr><tr><td>Gender diverse </td><td>A term that is used to describe people with gender behaviors, appearances, or identities that are incongruent with those culturally assigned to their birth sex; gender-diverse individuals may refer to themselves with many different terms, such as transgender, nonbinary, genderqueer,<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B7" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>7</sup></a> gender fluid, gender creative, gender independent, or noncisgender. “Gender diverse” is used to acknowledge and include the vast diversity of gender identities that exists. It replaces the former term, “gender nonconforming,” which has a negative and exclusionary connotation. </td></tr><tr><td>Transgender </td><td>A subset of gender-diverse youth whose gender identity does not match their assigned sex and generally remains persistent, consistent, and insistent over time; the term “transgender” also encompasses many other labels individuals may use to refer to themselves. </td></tr><tr><td>Cisgender </td><td>A term that is used to describe a person who identifies and expresses a gender that is consistent with the culturally defined norms of the sex they were assigned at birth </td></tr><tr><td>Agender </td><td>A term that is used to describe a person who does not identify as having a particular gender </td></tr><tr><td>Affirmed gender </td><td>When a person’s true gender identity, or concern about their gender identity, is communicated to and validated from others as authentic </td></tr><tr><td>MTF; affirmed female; trans female </td><td>Terms that are used to describe individuals who were assigned male sex at birth but who have a gender identity and/or expression that is asserted to be more feminine </td></tr><tr><td>FTM; affirmed male; trans male </td><td>Terms that are used to describe individuals who were assigned female sex at birth but who have a gender identity and/or expression that is asserted to be more masculine </td></tr><tr><td>Gender dysphoria </td><td>A clinical symptom that is characterized by a sense of alienation to some or all of the physical characteristics or social roles of one’s assigned gender; also, gender dysphoria is the psychiatric diagnosis in the <em>DSM-5</em>, which has focus on the distress that stems from the incongruence between one’s expressed or experienced (affirmed) gender and the gender assigned at birth. </td></tr><tr><td>Gender identity disorder </td><td>A psychiatric diagnosis defined previously in the <em>DSM-IV</em> (changed to “gender dysphoria” in the <em>DSM-5</em>); the primary criteria include a strong, persistent cross-sex identification and significant distress and social impairment. This diagnosis is no longer appropriate for use and may lead to stigma, but the term may be found in older research. </td></tr><tr><td>Sexual orientation </td><td>A person’s sexual identity in relation to the gender(s) to which they are attracted; sexual orientation and gender identity develop separately. </td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="table-wrap-foot"><div class="fn" content-id=""><p>This list is not intended to be all inclusive. The pronouns “they” and ”their” are used intentionally to be inclusive rather than the binary pronouns “he” and “she” and “his” and “her.” Adapted from Bonifacio HJ, Rosenthal SM. Gender variance and dysphoria in children and adolescents. <em>Pediatr Clin North Am</em>. 2015;62(4):1001–1016. Adapted from Vance SR Jr, Ehrensaft D, Rosenthal SM. Psychological and medical care of gender nonconforming youth. <em>Pediatrics</em>. 2014;134(6):1184–1192. DSM-5, <em>Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition</em>; DSM-IV, <em>Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition</em>; FTM, female to male; MTF, male to female.</p></div></div><div class="graphic-wrap "><a class="fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large" href="/view-large/7280789" target="_blank">View Large</a></div></div>
                </div>
                <div id="7280790" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>These labels may or may not be congruent. The term “cisgender” is used if someone identifies and expresses a gender that is consistent with the culturally defined norms of the sex that was assigned at birth. “Gender diverse” is an umbrella term to describe an ever-evolving array of labels that people may apply when their gender identity, expression, or even perception does not conform to the norms and stereotypes others expect of their assigned sex. “Transgender” is usually reserved for a subset of such youth whose gender identity does not match their assigned sex and generally remains persistent, consistent, and insistent over time. These terms are not diagnoses; rather, they are personal and often dynamic ways of describing one’s own gender experience.</p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280791" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Gender identity is not synonymous with “sexual orientation,” which refers to a person’s identity in relation to the gender(s) to which they are sexually and romantically attracted. Gender identity and sexual orientation are distinct but interrelated constructs.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B8" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>8</sup></a> Therefore, being transgender does not imply a sexual orientation, and people who identify as transgender still identify as straight, gay, bisexual, etc, on the basis of their attractions. (For more information, <em>The Gender Book</em>, found at <a class="link link-uri" href="http://www.thegenderbook.com" target="_blank">www.thegenderbook.com</a>, is a resource with illustrations that are used to highlight these core terms and concepts.)</p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h2 scrollto-destination="7280792" data-legacyid="s03" id="7280792" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Epidemiology</h2>
            <div >
                <div id="7280793" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>In population-based surveys, questions related to gender identity are rarely asked, which makes it difficult to assess the size and characteristics of the population that is TGD. In the 2014 Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, only 19 states elected to include optional questions on gender identity. Extrapolation from these data suggests that the US prevalence of adults who identify as transgender or “gender nonconforming” is 0.6% (1.4 million), ranging from 0.3% in North Dakota to 0.8% in Hawaii.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B9" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>9</sup></a> On the basis of these data, it has been estimated that 0.7% of youth ages 13 to 17 years (∼150 000) identify as transgender.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B10" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>10</sup></a> This number is much higher than previous estimates, which were extrapolated from individual states or specialty clinics, and is likely an underestimate given the stigma regarding those who openly identify as transgender and the difficulty in defining “transgender” in a way that is inclusive of all gender-diverse identities.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B11" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>11</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280794" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>There have been no large-scale prevalence studies among children and adolescents, and there is no evidence that adult statistics reflect young children or adolescents. In the 2014 Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System, those 18 to 24 years of age were more likely than older age groups to identify as transgender (0.7%).<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B9" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>9</sup></a> Children report being aware of gender incongruence at young ages. Children who later identify as TGD report first having recognized their gender as “different” at an average age of 8.5 years; however, they did not disclose such feelings until an average of 10 years later.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B12" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>12</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h2 scrollto-destination="7280795" data-legacyid="s04" id="7280795" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Mental Health Implications</h2>
            <div >
                <div id="7280796" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Adolescents and adults who identify as transgender have high rates of depression, anxiety, eating disorders, self-harm, and suicide.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B13" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>13</sup></a><sup>,</sup><sup>–</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B20" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>20</sup></a> Evidence suggests that an identity of TGD has an increased prevalence among individuals with autism spectrum disorder, but this association is not yet well understood.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B21" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>21</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B22" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>22</sup></a> In 1 retrospective cohort study, 56% of youth who identified as transgender reported previous suicidal ideation, and 31% reported a previous suicide attempt, compared with 20% and 11% among matched youth who identified as cisgender, respectively.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B13" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>13</sup></a> Some youth who identify as TGD also experience gender dysphoria, which is a specific diagnosis given to those who experience impairment in peer and/or family relationships, school performance, or other aspects of their life as a consequence of the incongruence between their assigned sex and their gender identity.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B23" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>23</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280797" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>There is no evidence that risk for mental illness is inherently attributable to one’s identity of TGD. Rather, it is believed to be multifactorial, stemming from an internal conflict between one’s appearance and identity, limited availability of mental health services, low access to health care providers with expertise in caring for youth who identify as TGD, discrimination, stigma, and social rejection.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B24" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>24</sup></a> This was affirmed by the American Psychological Association in 2008<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B25" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>25</sup></a> (with practice guidelines released in 2015<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B8" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>8</sup></a>) and the American Psychiatric Association, which made the following statement in 2012:</p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280798" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <div class="blockquote-wrap" id=""><blockquote><p><em>Being transgender or gender variant implies no impairment in judgment, stability, reliability, or general social or vocational capabilities; however, these individuals often experience discrimination due to a lack of civil rights protections for their gender identity or expression.… [Such] discrimination and lack of equal civil rights is damaging to the mental health of transgender and gender variant individuals</em>.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B26" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>26</sup></a> </p></blockquote></div>
                </div>
                <div id="7280799" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Youth who identify as TGD often confront stigma and discrimination, which contribute to feelings of rejection and isolation that can adversely affect physical and emotional well-being. For example, many youth believe that they must hide their gender identity and expression to avoid bullying, harassment, or victimization. Youth who identify as TGD experience disproportionately high rates of homelessness, physical violence (at home and in the community), substance abuse, and high-risk sexual behaviors.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B5" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>5</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B6" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>6</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B12" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>12</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B27" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>27</sup></a><sup>,</sup><sup>–</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B31" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>31</sup></a> Among the 3 million HIV testing events that were reported in 2015, the highest percentages of new infections were among women who identified as transgender<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B32" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>32</sup></a> and were also at particular risk for not knowing their HIV status.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B30" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>30</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h2 scrollto-destination="7280800" data-legacyid="s05" id="7280800" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Gender-Affirmative Care</h2>
            <div >
                <div id="7280801" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>In a gender-affirmative care model (GACM), pediatric providers offer developmentally appropriate care that is oriented toward understanding and appreciating the youth’s gender experience. A strong, nonjudgmental partnership with youth and their families can facilitate exploration of complicated emotions and gender-diverse expressions while allowing questions and concerns to be raised in a supportive environment.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B5" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>5</sup></a> In a GACM, the following messages are conveyed:</p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280802" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <ul class="bullet"><li><p>transgender identities and diverse gender expressions do not constitute a mental disorder;</p></li><li><p>variations in gender identity and expression are normal aspects of human diversity, and binary definitions of gender do not always reflect emerging gender identities;</p></li><li><p>gender identity evolves as an interplay of biology, development, socialization, and culture; and</p></li><li><p>if a mental health issue exists, it most often stems from stigma and negative experiences rather than being intrinsic to the child.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B27" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>27</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B33" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>33</sup></a> </p></li></ul>
                </div>
                <div id="7280803" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>The GACM is best facilitated through the integration of medical, mental health, and social services, including specific resources and supports for parents and families.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B24" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>24</sup></a> Providers work together to destigmatize gender variance, promote the child’s self-worth, facilitate access to care, educate families, and advocate for safer community spaces where children are free to develop and explore their gender.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B5" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>5</sup></a> A specialized gender-affirmative therapist, when available, may be an asset in helping children and their families build skills for dealing with gender-based stigma, address symptoms of anxiety or depression, and reinforce the child’s overall resiliency.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B34" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>34</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B35" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>35</sup></a> There is a limited but growing body of evidence that suggests that using an integrated affirmative model results in young people having fewer mental health concerns whether they ultimately identify as transgender.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B24" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>24</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B36" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>36</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B37" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>37</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280804" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>In contrast, “conversion” or “reparative” treatment models are used to prevent children and adolescents from identifying as transgender or to dissuade them from exhibiting gender-diverse expressions. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration has concluded that any therapeutic intervention with the goal of changing a youth’s gender expression or identity is inappropriate.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B33" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>33</sup></a> Reparative approaches have been proven to be not only unsuccessful<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B38" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>38</sup></a> but also deleterious and are considered outside the mainstream of traditional medical practice.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B29" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>29</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B39" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>39</sup></a><sup>,</sup><sup>–</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B42" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>42</sup></a> The AAP described reparative approaches as “unfair and deceptive.”<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B43" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>43</sup></a> At the time of this writing,<sup><a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="fn11" data-open="fn11" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn split-view-modal">*</a></sup> conversion therapy was banned by executive regulation in New York and by legislative statutes in 9 other states as well as the District of Columbia.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B44" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>44</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280805" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Pediatric providers have an essential role in assessing gender concerns and providing evidence-based information to assist youth and families in medical decision-making. Not doing so can prolong or exacerbate gender dysphoria and contribute to abuse and stigmatization.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B35" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>35</sup></a> If a pediatric provider does not feel prepared to address gender concerns when they occur, then referral to a pediatric or mental health provider with more expertise is appropriate. There is little research on communication and efficacy with transfers in care for youth who identify as TGD, particularly from pediatric to adult providers.</p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h2 scrollto-destination="7280806" data-legacyid="s06" id="7280806" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Developmental Considerations</h2>
            <div >
                <div id="7280807" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Acknowledging that the capacity for emerging abstract thinking in childhood is important to conceptualize and reflect on identity, gender-affirmation guidelines are being focused on individually tailored interventions on the basis of the physical and cognitive development of youth who identify as TGD.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B45" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>45</sup></a> Accordingly, research substantiates that children who are prepubertal and assert an identity of TGD know their gender as clearly and as consistently as their developmentally equivalent peers who identify as cisgender and benefit from the same level of social acceptance.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B46" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>46</sup></a> This developmental approach to gender affirmation is in contrast to the outdated approach in which a child’s gender-diverse assertions are held as “possibly true” until an arbitrary age (often after pubertal onset) when they can be considered valid, an approach that authors of the literature have termed “watchful waiting.” This outdated approach does not serve the child because critical support is withheld. Watchful waiting is based on binary notions of gender in which gender diversity and fluidity is pathologized; in watchful waiting, it is also assumed that notions of gender identity become fixed at a certain age. The approach is also influenced by a group of early studies with validity concerns, methodologic flaws, and limited follow-up on children who identified as TGD and, by adolescence, did not seek further treatment (“desisters”).<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B45" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>45</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B47" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>47</sup></a> More robust and current research suggests that, rather than focusing on who a child will become, valuing them for who they are, even at a young age, fosters secure attachment and resilience, not only for the child but also for the whole family.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B5" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>5</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B45" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>45</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B48" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>48</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B49" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>49</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h2 scrollto-destination="7280808" data-legacyid="s07" id="7280808" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Medical Management</h2>
            <div >
                <div id="7280809" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Pediatric primary care providers are in a unique position to routinely inquire about gender development in children and adolescents as part of recommended well-child visits<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B50" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>50</sup></a> and to be a reliable source of validation, support, and reassurance. They are often the first provider to be aware that a child may not identify as cisgender or that there may be distress related to a gender-diverse identity. The best way to approach gender with patients is to inquire directly and nonjudgmentally about their experience and feelings before applying any labels.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B27" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>27</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B51" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>51</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280810" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Many medical interventions can be offered to youth who identify as TGD and their families. The decision of whether and when to initiate gender-affirmative treatment is personal and involves careful consideration of risks, benefits, and other factors unique to each patient and family. Many protocols suggest that clinical assessment of youth who identify as TGD is ideally conducted on an ongoing basis in the setting of a collaborative, multidisciplinary approach, which, in addition to the patient and family, may include the pediatric provider, a mental health provider (preferably with expertise in caring for youth who identify as TGD ), social and legal supports, and a pediatric endocrinologist or adolescent-medicine gender specialist, if available.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B6" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>6</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B28" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>28</sup></a> There is no prescribed path, sequence, or end point. Providers can make every effort to be aware of the influence of their own biases. The medical options also vary depending on pubertal and developmental progression.</p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h3 scrollto-destination="7280811" data-legacyid="s08" id="7280811" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Clinical Setting</h3>
            <div >
                <div id="7280812" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>In the past year, 1 in 4 adults who identified as transgender avoided a necessary doctor’s visit because of fear of being mistreated.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B31" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>31</sup></a> All clinical office staff have a role in affirming a patient’s gender identity. Making flyers available or displaying posters related to LGBTQ health issues, including information for children who identify as TGD and families, reveals inclusivity and awareness. Generally, patients who identify as TGD feel most comfortable when they have access to a gender-neutral restroom. Diversity training that encompasses sensitivity when caring for youth who identify as TGD and their families can be helpful in educating clinical and administrative staff. A patient-asserted name and pronouns are used by staff and are ideally reflected in the electronic medical record without creating duplicate charts.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B52" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>52</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B53" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>53</sup></a> The US Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services and the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology require all electronic health record systems certified under the Meaningful Use incentive program to have the capacity to confidentially collect information on gender identity.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B54" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>54</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B55" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>55</sup></a> Explaining and maintaining confidentiality procedures promotes openness and trust, particularly with youth who identify as LGBTQ.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B1" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>1</sup></a> Maintaining a safe clinical space can provide at least 1 consistent, protective refuge for patients and families, allowing authentic gender expression and exploration that builds resiliency.</p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h3 scrollto-destination="7280813" data-legacyid="s09" id="7280813" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Pubertal Suppression</h3>
            <div >
                <div id="7280814" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Gonadotrophin-releasing hormones have been used to delay puberty since the 1980s for central precocious puberty.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B56" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>56</sup></a> These reversible treatments can also be used in adolescents who experience gender dysphoria to prevent development of secondary sex characteristics and provide time up until 16 years of age for the individual and the family to explore gender identity, access psychosocial supports, develop coping skills, and further define appropriate treatment goals. If pubertal suppression treatment is suspended, then endogenous puberty will resume.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B20" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>20</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B57" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>57</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B58" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>58</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280815" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Often, pubertal suppression creates an opportunity to reduce distress that may occur with the development of secondary sexual characteristics and allow for gender-affirming care, including mental health support for the adolescent and the family. It reduces the need for later surgery because physical changes that are otherwise irreversible (protrusion of the Adam’s apple, male pattern baldness, voice change, breast growth, etc) are prevented. The available data reveal that pubertal suppression in children who identify as TGD generally leads to improved psychological functioning in adolescence and young adulthood.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B20" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>20</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B57" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>57</sup></a><sup>,</sup><sup>–</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B59" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>59</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280816" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Pubertal suppression is not without risks. Delaying puberty beyond one’s peers can also be stressful and can lead to lower self-esteem and increased risk taking.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B60" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>60</sup></a> Some experts believe that genital underdevelopment may limit some potential reconstructive options.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B61" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>61</sup></a> Research on long-term risks, particularly in terms of bone metabolism<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B62" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>62</sup></a> and fertility,<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B63" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>63</sup></a> is currently limited and provides varied results.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B57" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>57</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B64" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>64</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B65" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>65</sup></a> Families often look to pediatric providers for help in considering whether pubertal suppression is indicated in the context of their child’s overall well-being as gender diverse.</p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h3 scrollto-destination="7280817" data-legacyid="s10" id="7280817" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Gender Affirmation</h3>
            <div >
                <div id="7280818" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>As youth who identify as TGD reflect on and evaluate their gender identity, various interventions may be considered to better align their gender expression with their underlying identity. This process of reflection, acceptance, and, for some, intervention is known as “gender affirmation.” It was formerly referred to as “transitioning,” but many view the process as an affirmation and acceptance of who they have always been rather than a transition from 1 gender identity to another. Accordingly, some people who have gone through the process prefer to call themselves “affirmed females, males, etc” (or just “females, males, etc”), rather than using the prefix “trans-.” Gender affirmation is also used to acknowledge that some individuals who identify as TGD may feel affirmed in their gender without pursuing medical or surgical interventions.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B7" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>7</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B66" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>66</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280819" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Supportive involvement of parents and family is associated with better mental and physical health outcomes.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B67" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>67</sup></a> Gender affirmation among adolescents with gender dysphoria often reduces the emphasis on gender in their lives, allowing them to attend to other developmental tasks, such as academic success, relationship building, and future-oriented planning.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B64" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>64</sup></a> Most protocols for gender-affirming interventions incorporate World Professional Association of Transgender Health<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B35" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>35</sup></a> and Endocrine Society<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B68" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>68</sup></a> recommendations and include ≥1 of the following elements (<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="t2" data-open="t2" class="link link-reveal link-table xref-fig">Table 2</a>):</p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280820" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <a id = "7280820" scrollto-destination="7280820"></a><div content-id="t2 s10" class="table-wrap table-wide"><div id="t2" data-id="t2" class="table-wrap-title "><span class="label">TABLE 2</span><div class="caption"><p>The Process of Gender Affirmation May Include ≥1 of the Following Components</p></div> </div><div class="table-overflow"><table><thead name="thead" align=""><tr><th>Component<span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th><th>Definition<span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th><th>General Age Range<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="tt2n1" data-open="tt2n1" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn"><sup>a</sup></a><span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th><th>Reversibility<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="tt2n1" data-open="tt2n1" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn"><sup>a</sup></a><span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Social affirmation </td><td>Adopting gender-affirming hairstyles, clothing, name, gender pronouns, and restrooms and other facilities </td><td>Any </td><td>Reversible </td></tr><tr><td>Puberty blockers </td><td>Gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues, such as leuprolide and histrelin </td><td>During puberty (Tanner stage 2–5)<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="tt2n2" data-open="tt2n2" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn"><sup>b</sup></a> </td><td>Reversible<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="tt2n3" data-open="tt2n3" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn"><sup>c</sup></a> </td></tr><tr><td>Cross-sex hormone therapy </td><td>Testosterone (for those who were assigned female at birth and are masculinizing); estrogen plus androgen inhibitor (for those who were assigned male at birth and are feminizing) </td><td>Early adolescence onward </td><td>Partially reversible (skin texture, muscle mass, and fat deposition); irreversible once developed (testosterone: Adam’s apple protrusion, voice changes, and male pattern baldness; estrogen: breast development); unknown reversibility (effect on fertility) </td></tr><tr><td>Gender-affirming surgeries </td><td>“Top” surgery (to create a male-typical chest shape or enhance breasts); “bottom” surgery (surgery on genitals or reproductive organs); facial feminization and other procedures </td><td>Typically adults (adolescents on case-by-case basis<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="tt2n4" data-open="tt2n4" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn"><sup>d</sup></a>) </td><td>Not reversible </td></tr><tr><td>Legal affirmation </td><td>Changing gender and name recorded on birth certificate, school records, and other documents </td><td>Any </td><td>Reversible </td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="table-modal"><table><thead name="thead" align=""><tr><th>Component<span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th><th>Definition<span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th><th>General Age Range<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="tt2n1" data-open="tt2n1" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn"><sup>a</sup></a><span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th><th>Reversibility<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="tt2n1" data-open="tt2n1" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn"><sup>a</sup></a><span aria-hidden="true" style="display: none;">
            . </span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Social affirmation </td><td>Adopting gender-affirming hairstyles, clothing, name, gender pronouns, and restrooms and other facilities </td><td>Any </td><td>Reversible </td></tr><tr><td>Puberty blockers </td><td>Gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues, such as leuprolide and histrelin </td><td>During puberty (Tanner stage 2–5)<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="tt2n2" data-open="tt2n2" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn"><sup>b</sup></a> </td><td>Reversible<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="tt2n3" data-open="tt2n3" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn"><sup>c</sup></a> </td></tr><tr><td>Cross-sex hormone therapy </td><td>Testosterone (for those who were assigned female at birth and are masculinizing); estrogen plus androgen inhibitor (for those who were assigned male at birth and are feminizing) </td><td>Early adolescence onward </td><td>Partially reversible (skin texture, muscle mass, and fat deposition); irreversible once developed (testosterone: Adam’s apple protrusion, voice changes, and male pattern baldness; estrogen: breast development); unknown reversibility (effect on fertility) </td></tr><tr><td>Gender-affirming surgeries </td><td>“Top” surgery (to create a male-typical chest shape or enhance breasts); “bottom” surgery (surgery on genitals or reproductive organs); facial feminization and other procedures </td><td>Typically adults (adolescents on case-by-case basis<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="tt2n4" data-open="tt2n4" class="link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn"><sup>d</sup></a>) </td><td>Not reversible </td></tr><tr><td>Legal affirmation </td><td>Changing gender and name recorded on birth certificate, school records, and other documents </td><td>Any </td><td>Reversible </td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="table-wrap-foot"><div class="fn" content-id="tt2n1"><span class="label fn-label"><span rel="nofollow" data-fn-id="tt2n1" class="end-note-link">a</span></span><p>Note that the provided age range and reversibility is based on the little data that are currently available.</p></div><div class="fn" content-id="tt2n2"><span class="label fn-label"><span rel="nofollow" data-fn-id="tt2n2" class="end-note-link">b</span></span><p>There is limited benefit to starting gonadotropin-releasing hormone after Tanner stage 5 for pubertal suppression. However, when cross-sex hormones are initiated with a gradually increasing schedule, the initial levels are often not high enough to suppress endogenous sex hormone secretion. Therefore, gonadotropin-releasing hormone may be continued in accordance with the Endocrine Society Guidelines.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B68" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>68</sup></a> </p></div><div class="fn" content-id="tt2n3"><span class="label fn-label"><span rel="nofollow" data-fn-id="tt2n3" class="end-note-link">c</span></span><p>The effect of sustained puberty suppression on fertility is unknown. Pubertal suppression can be, and often is indicated to be, followed by cross-sex hormone treatment. However, when cross-sex hormones are initiated without endogenous hormones, then fertility may be decreased.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B68" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>68</sup></a> </p></div><div class="fn" content-id="tt2n4"><span class="label fn-label"><span rel="nofollow" data-fn-id="tt2n4" class="end-note-link">d</span></span><p>Eligibility criteria for gender-affirmative surgical interventions among adolescents are not clearly defined between established protocols and practice. When applicable, eligibility is usually determined on a case-by-case basis with the adolescent and the family along with input from medical, mental health, and surgical providers.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B68" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>68</sup></a><sup>,</sup><sup>–</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B71" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>71</sup></a> </p></div></div><div class="graphic-wrap "><a class="fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large" href="/view-large/7280820" target="_blank">View Large</a></div></div>
                </div>
                <div id="7280821" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <ol class="number"><li><p>Social Affirmation: This is a reversible intervention in which children and adolescents express partially or completely in their asserted gender identity by adapting hairstyle, clothing, pronouns, name, etc. Children who identify as transgender and socially affirm and are supported in their asserted gender show no increase in depression and only minimal (clinically insignificant) increases in anxiety compared with age-matched averages.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B48" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>48</sup></a> Social affirmation can be complicated given the wide range of social interactions children have (eg, extended families, peers, school, community, etc). There is little guidance on the best approach (eg, all at once, gradual, creating new social networks, or affirming within existing networks, etc). Pediatric providers can best support families by anticipating and discussing such complexity proactively, either in their own practice or through enlisting a qualified mental health provider.</p></li><li><p>Legal Affirmation: Elements of a social affirmation, such as a name and gender marker, become official on legal documents, such as birth certificates, passports, identification cards, school documents, etc. The processes for making these changes depend on state laws and may require specific documentation from pediatric providers.</p></li><li><p>Medical Affirmation: This is the process of using cross-sex hormones to allow adolescents who have initiated puberty to develop secondary sex characteristics of the opposite biological sex. Some changes are partially reversible if hormones are stopped, but others become irreversible once they are fully developed (<a href="javascript:;" reveal-id="t2" data-open="t2" class="link link-reveal link-table xref-fig">Table 2</a>).</p></li><li><p>Surgical Affirmation: Surgical approaches may be used to feminize or masculinize features, such as hair distribution, chest, or genitalia, and may include removal of internal organs, such as ovaries or the uterus (affecting fertility). These changes are irreversible. Although current protocols typically reserve surgical interventions for adults,<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B35" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>35</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B68" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>68</sup></a> they are occasionally pursued during adolescence on a case-by-case basis, considering the necessity and benefit to the adolescent’s overall health and often including multidisciplinary input from medical, mental health, and surgical providers as well as from the adolescent and family.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B69" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>69</sup></a><sup>,</sup><sup>–</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B71" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>71</sup></a> </p></li></ol>
                </div>
                <div id="7280822" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>For some youth who identify as TGD whose natal gender is female, menstruation, breakthrough bleeding, and dysmenorrhea can lead to significant distress before or during gender affirmation. The American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology suggests that, although limited data are available to outline management, menstruation can be managed without exogenous estrogens by using a progesterone-only pill, a medroxyprogesterone acetate shot, or a progesterone-containing intrauterine or implantable device.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B72" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>72</sup></a> If estrogen can be tolerated, oral contraceptives that contain both progesterone and estrogen are more effective at suppressing menses.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B73" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>73</sup></a> The Endocrine Society guidelines also suggest that gonadotrophin-releasing hormones can be used for menstrual suppression before the anticipated initiation of testosterone or in combination with testosterone for breakthrough bleeding (enables phenotypic masculinization at a lower dose than if testosterone is used alone).<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B68" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>68</sup></a> Masculinizing hormones in natal female patients may lead to a cessation of menses, but unplanned pregnancies have been reported, which emphasizes the need for ongoing contraceptive counseling with youth who identify as TGD.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B72" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>72</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h2 scrollto-destination="7280823" data-legacyid="s11" id="7280823" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Health Disparities</h2>
            <div >
                <div id="7280824" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>In addition to societal challenges, youth who identify as TGD face several barriers within the health care system, especially regarding access to care. In 2015, a focus group of youth who identified as transgender in Seattle, Washington, revealed 4 problematic areas related to health care:</p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280825" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <ol class="number"><li><p>safety issues, including the lack of safe clinical environments and fear of discrimination by providers;</p></li><li><p>poor access to physical health services, including testing for sexually transmitted infections;</p></li><li><p>inadequate resources to address mental health concerns; and</p></li><li><p>lack of continuity with providers.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B74" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>74</sup></a> </p></li></ol>
                </div>
                <div id="7280826" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>This study reveals the obstacles many youth who identify as TGD face in accessing essential services, including the limited supply of appropriately trained medical and psychological providers, fertility options, and insurance coverage denials for gender-related treatments.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B74" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>74</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280827" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Insurance denials for services related to the care of patients who identify as TGD are a significant barrier. Although the Office for Civil Rights of the US Department of Health and Human Services explicitly stated in 2012 that the nondiscrimination provision in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act includes people who identify as gender diverse,<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B75" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>75</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B76" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>76</sup></a> insurance claims for gender affirmation, particularly among youth who identify as TGD, are frequently denied.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B54" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>54</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B77" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>77</sup></a> In 1 study, it was found that approximately 25% of individuals who identified as transgender were denied insurance coverage because of being transgender.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B31" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>31</sup></a> The burden of covering medical expenses that are not covered by insurance can be financially devastating, and even when expenses are covered, families describe high levels of stress in navigating and submitting claims appropriately.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B78" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>78</sup></a> In 2012, a large gender center in Boston, Massachusetts, reported that most young patients who identified as transgender and were deemed appropriate candidates for recommended gender care were unable to obtain it because of such denials, which were based on the premise that gender dysphoria was a mental disorder, not a physical one, and that treatment was not medically or surgically necessary.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B24" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>24</sup></a> This practice not only contributes to stigma, prolonged gender dysphoria, and poor mental health outcomes,<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B77" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>77</sup></a> but it may also lead patients to seek nonmedically supervised treatments that are potentially dangerous.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B24" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>24</sup></a> Furthermore, insurance denials can reinforce a socioeconomic divide between those who can finance the high costs of uncovered care and those who cannot.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B24" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>24</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B77" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>77</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280828" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>The transgender youth group in Seattle likely reflected the larger TGD population when they described how obstacles adversely affect self-esteem and contribute to the perception that they are undervalued by society and the health care system.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B74" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>74</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B77" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>77</sup></a> Professional medical associations, including the AAP, are increasingly calling for equity in health care provisions regardless of gender identity or expression.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B1" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>1</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B8" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>8</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B23" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>23</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B72" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>72</sup></a> There is a critical need for investments in research on the prevalence, disparities, biological underpinnings, and standards of care relating to gender-diverse populations. Pediatric providers who work with state government and insurance officials can play an essential role in advocating for stronger nondiscrimination policies and improved coverage.</p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280829" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>There is a lack of quality research on the experience of youth of color who identify as transgender. One theory suggests that the intersection of racism, transphobia, and sexism may result in the extreme marginalization that is experienced among many women of color who identify as transgender,<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B79" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>79</sup></a> including rejection from their family and dropping out of school at younger ages (often in the setting of rigid religious beliefs regarding gender),<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B80" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>80</sup></a> increased levels of violence and body objectification,<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B81" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>81</sup></a> 3 times the risk of poverty compared with the general population,<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B31" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>31</sup></a> and the highest prevalence of HIV compared with other risk groups (estimated as high as 56.3% in 1 meta-analysis).<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B30" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>30</sup></a> One model suggests that pervasive stigma and oppression can be associated with psychological distress (anxiety, depression, and suicide) and adoption of risk behaviors by such youth to obtain a sense of validation toward their complex identities.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B79" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>79</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h2 scrollto-destination="7280830" data-legacyid="s12" id="7280830" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Family Acceptance</h2>
            <div >
                <div id="7280831" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Research increasingly suggests that familial acceptance or rejection ultimately has little influence on the gender identity of youth; however, it may profoundly affect young people’s ability to openly discuss or disclose concerns about their identity. Suppressing such concerns can affect mental health.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B82" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>82</sup></a> Families often find it hard to understand and accept their child’s gender-diverse traits because of personal beliefs, social pressure, and stigma.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B49" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>49</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B83" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>83</sup></a> Legitimate fears may exist for their child’s welfare, safety, and acceptance that pediatric providers need to appreciate and address. Families can be encouraged to communicate their concerns and questions. Unacknowledged concerns can contribute to shame and hesitation in regard to offering support and understanding,<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B84" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>84</sup></a> which is essential for the child’s self-esteem, social involvement, and overall health as TGD.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B48" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>48</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B85" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>85</sup></a><sup>,</sup><sup>–</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B87" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>87</sup></a> Some caution has been expressed that unquestioning acceptance per se may not best serve questioning youth or their families. Instead, psychological evidence suggests that the most benefit comes when family members and youth are supported and encouraged to engage in reflective perspective taking and validate their own and the other’s thoughts and feelings despite divergent views.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B49" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>49</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B82" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>82</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280832" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>In this regard, suicide attempt rates among 433 adolescents in Ontario who identified as “trans” were 4% among those with strongly supportive parents and as high as 60% among those whose parents were not supportive.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B85" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>85</sup></a> Adolescents who identify as transgender and endorse at least 1 supportive person in their life report significantly less distress than those who only experience rejection. In communities with high levels of support, it was found that nonsupportive families tended to increase their support over time, leading to dramatic improvement in mental health outcomes among their children who identified as transgender.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B88" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>88</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280833" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Pediatric providers can create a safe environment for parents and families to better understand and listen to the needs of their children while receiving reassurance and education.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B83" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>83</sup></a> It is often appropriate to assist the child in understanding the parents’ concerns as well. Despite expectations by some youth with transgender identity for immediate acceptance after “coming out,” family members often proceed through a process of becoming more comfortable and understanding of the youth’s gender identity, thoughts, and feelings. One model suggests that the process resembles grieving, wherein the family separates from their expectations for their child to embrace a new reality. This process may proceed through stages of shock, denial, anger, feelings of betrayal, fear, self-discovery, and pride.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B89" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>89</sup></a> The amount of time spent in any of these stages and the overall pace varies widely. Many family members also struggle as they are pushed to reflect on their own gender experience and assumptions throughout this process. In some situations, youth who identify as TGD may be at risk for internalizing the difficult emotions that family members may be experiencing. In these cases, individual and group therapy for the family members may be helpful.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B49" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>49</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B78" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>78</sup></a> </p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280834" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Family dynamics can be complex, involving disagreement among legal guardians or between guardians and their children, which may affect the ability to obtain consent for any medical management or interventions. Even in states where minors may access care without parental consent for mental health services, contraception, and sexually transmitted infections, parental or guardian consent is required for hormonal and surgical care of patients who identify as TGD.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B72" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>72</sup></a><sup>,</sup><a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B90" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>90</sup></a> Some families may take issue with providers who address gender concerns or offer gender-affirming care. In rare cases, a family may deny access to care that raises concerns about the youth’s welfare and safety; in those cases, additional legal or ethical support may be useful to consider. In such rare situations, pediatric providers may want to familiarize themselves with relevant local consent laws and maintain their primary responsibility for the welfare of the child.</p>
                </div>
                </div>
            <h2 scrollto-destination="7280835" data-legacyid="s13" id="7280835" class="section-title jumplink-heading">Safe Schools and Communities</h2>
            <div >
                <div id="7280836" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
                    
                    <p>Youth who identify as TGD are becoming more visible because gender-diverse expression is increasingly admissible in the media, on social media, and in schools and communities. Regardless of whether a youth with a gender-diverse identity ultimately identifies as transgender, challenges exist in nearly every social context, from lack of understanding to outright rejection, isolation, discrimination, and victimization. In the US Transgender Survey of nearly 28 000 respondents, it was found that among those who were out as or perceived to be TGD between kindergarten and eighth grade, 54% were verbally harassed, 24% were physically assaulted, and 13% were sexually assaulted; 17% left school because of maltreatment.<a href="javascript:;" data-modal-source-id="B31" class="link link-ref xref-bibr"><sup>31</sup></a> Education and advocacy from the medical community on the importance of safe schools for youth who identify as TGD can have a significant effect.</p>
                </div>
                <div id="7280837" class="article-section-wrapper js-article-section js-content-section  ">
